demos.title: Order Historical Events
demos.description: Basic ordering task with historical events in chronological order

correct.custom: Excellent! You correctly ordered these historical events chronologically.

incorrect.custom: Not quite. Review the timeline of these events.

partial.custom: You're getting there! Some events are in the correct order.

model.prompt: Arrange these historical events in chronological order from earliest to latest:
model.rationale: The correct chronological order is: Declaration of Independence (1776), American Revolution (1775-1783), World War II Ends (1945), Moon Landing (1969).
model.teacherInstructions: Students should order events from earliest to latest. Partial credit is given for each correctly positioned event.

demos.title: Order Mathematical Equations
demos.description: Order equations by complexity with LaTeX math rendering

correct.custom: Perfect! You correctly ordered the equations from simplest to most complex.

incorrect.custom: Incorrect. Consider the degree and number of terms in each equation.

partial.custom: Good progress! Some equations are correctly positioned.

model.prompt: Order these equations from simplest to most complex:
model.rationale: Complexity is determined by the degree of the polynomial: linear equations (degree 1) are simplest, then quadratic (degree 2), then cubic (degree 3).
model.teacherInstructions: Students should recognize that equation complexity increases with polynomial degree: linear (x), quadratic (x²), cubic (x³).

demos.title: Order Planets by Distance
demos.description: Order planets from closest to farthest from the Sun with mixed content

correct.custom: Excellent! You correctly ordered the planets by distance from the Sun.

incorrect.custom: Not quite right. Remember: My Very Educated Mother Just Served Us...

partial.custom: You're on the right track! Some planets are in the correct position.

model.prompt: Arrange these planets in order from closest to farthest from the Sun:
model.rationale: The order of planets from the Sun is: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune. This follows the mnemonic: My Very Educated Mother Just Served Us Nachos.
model.teacherInstructions: This exercise tests students' knowledge of the solar system. The horizontal orientation provides a visual representation of the planets' positions.

demos.title: Order Equation Solving Steps
demos.description: Order the steps to solve a quadratic equation with mathematical notation

correct.custom: Perfect! You correctly ordered the steps to solve the quadratic equation.

incorrect.custom: Review the order of operations for solving quadratic equations using the quadratic formula.

partial.custom: Good effort! You have some steps in the correct order.

model.prompt: Arrange these steps in the correct order to solve the quadratic equation:
model.rationale: To solve a quadratic equation: (1) Write the equation in standard form, (2) Identify coefficients a, b, and c, (3) Apply the quadratic formula, (4) Substitute values, (5) Simplify to find solutions.
model.teacherInstructions: This question assesses students' understanding of the systematic approach to solving quadratic equations using the quadratic formula. Each step builds upon the previous one.
